citation.article-title: A new species of brown-pigmented agarolytic bacteria of the genus Alteromonas.

p.s: Description of Alteromonas fuliginea sp. nov.
Alteromonas fuliginea (Fu. li. gi. nea. L. adj. fuliginea - black-brown)
Rod-shaped cells with rounded ends.
Dimensions: length 1.5-1.8 μm, diameter 0.5-0.8 μmm.
Flagellated, motile.
The cells occur singly, sometimes in pairs.
Gram-negative, strictly aerobic.
Do not produce spores or capsules.
On complex media containing sea water, they form black or brown smooth, convex, glossy colonies 3-5 mm in diameter.
Synthesis of melanin-like pigment is intensive at temperatures from 4 to 10°C.
The cells require sea water or 1-6% sodium chloride for growth.
They do not grow in the absence of Na ion.
The cells grow at pH values from 6.0 and 9.0, the optimum pH being 7.5 to 8.5.
Their growth temperature ranges from 4 to 35°e.
The cells do not grow at 40°C.
The cells are chemoorganoheterotrophs.
They utilize citrate, caprate, phenylacetate, tyrosine, and arginine as a source of carbon and energy.
They also utilize yeast extract, caseine hydrolyzate, gelatin, Tween-80, and DNA.
They do not utilize alcohols or sugars.
The cells display catalase, oxidase, and β-galactosidase activities.
They digest agar, carrageenan, alginic acids, esculin, and starch.
They do not digest N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, chitin, or cellulose.
The (G + C) content of their DNA ranges from 41.5 to 43.8 mole%.
Strain KMM 216 is chosen as the type strain.
It is isolated from the homogenate of purple sea squirt Halocynthia aurantium inhabiting the coastal waters of Peter the Great Bay in the Sea of Japan.
The description of the strain corresponds to that of the type species.
The strain is deposited in the Collection of Marine Microorganisms (KMM) of the Pacific Ocean Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry, Far East Branch of Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok.
